articles.description: “It doesn’t necessarily mean that you have cancer. But the more you smoke, the more mutations accumulate in your cells, and the more you increase your risk for developing cancer," said study author Marcos Díaz-Gay, PhD.
articles.content: A powerful new machine learning tool developed by experts at the University of California San Diego (UCSD) has discovered a pattern of DNA mutations that links bladder cancer to tobacco smoking. The … [+3522 chars]
